title: What are Euclid's first 5 postulates? - Quora

response.answer_text: Euclid’s Postulates were a set of rules Euclid believed to be so fundamental that they could not be proven using any other basic rules. Essentially, to prove something, you need to make assumptions, as otherwise you have nothing to start with. For Euclid, these assumptions were as follows: 1. A straight line segment can be drawn joining any two points. 2. Any straight line segment can be extended indefinitely in a straight line. 3. Given any straight line segment, a circle can be drawn having the segment as radius and one endpoint as center. 4. All right angles are congruent. 5. If two lines are drawn which intersect a third in such a way that the sum of the inner angles on one side is less than two right angles, then the two lines are not parallel, and must intersect. Everything else Euclid did was based on these postulates, and proven as long as these are correct. Additionally, anything you prove using these postulates can also be used in future proofs, as it is equally true. These are the building blocks for what is known as “Euclidean Geometry”; essentially, geometry on a rectangular plane. Euclid himself believed that the fifth postulate, the so-called “Parallel Postulate”, could be proven using the other four postulates (making it a theorem, not a postulate), but it turns out to be a crucial part of what makes this Euclidean. Take it away, add a different postulate, and you can get hyperbolic geometry, which is a completely different field of geometry.

The question is: “What are the four Euclid[ian] postulates?” There are, in fact, five. They are: a straight line segment can be drawn joining any two pointsany line segment can be extended indefinitely into a straight linegiven a line segment, a circle can be drawn having the length of the segment as radius and one end as the centerall right angles are congruentif two lines are drawn to intersect a third, and the sum of the inner angles on one side of the third line is less than two right angles, then the two lines must intersect… these form the basis of Euclidean geometry, and define “flat space”. There are, in effect, unspoken presuppositions about what constitutes a point, a line, and straightness. This is something that is easily googled — check it out: Euclid's Postulates

A straight line segment may be drawn from any given point to any other.A straight line may be extended to any finite length.A circle may be described with any given point as its center and any distance as its radius.All right angles are congruent.If a straight line intersects two other straight lines, and so makes the two interior angles on one side of it together less than two right angles, then the other straight lines will meet at a point if extended far enough on the side on which the angles are less than two right angles.

To draw a straight line between any point and any other pointTo produce a finite straight line continuously in a straight line To describe a circle with any center and radiusThat all right angles equal one anotherThat, if a straight line falling on two straight lines makes the interior angles on the same side less than two right angles, the two straight lines, if produced indefinitely, meet on that side on which are the angles less than the two right angles.

They are five axioms used by Euclid to describe geometry of the space we experience in daily life, and which was the only geometry considered at his time. He also made some other assumptions, some explicitly and other implicitly.

A postulate is a statement that suggests or assumes the existence, fact, or truth of (something) as a basis for reasoning, discussion, or belief. Euclid's postulates are postulates by Euclid that were given to explain some basic ideas in geometry and arithmetic
